description: Style template for intelligent document formatting. Each user style in 'userStyles' includes a 'whenToApply' field describing the situations where that style should be applied. The 'wdStyleDefinitions' section contains Word style definitions that can optionally be created/updated in target documents.

userStyles.whenToApply: APPLY TO THE MAIN DOCUMENT TITLE AT THE VERY TOP. USUALLY CENTERED, BOLD, LARGER FONT. EXAMPLES: 'ASSET PURCHASE AGREEMENT', 'EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT', 'NON-DISCLOSURE AGREEMENT'. APPEARS ONLY ONCE AT DOCUMENT START.

APPLY TO MAJOR SECTION HEADINGS THAT DIVIDE THE DOCUMENT INTO ARTICLES OR MAIN PARTS. USUALLY ALL CAPS OR BOLD, OFTEN PRECEDED BY 'ARTICLE', 'SECTION', OR ROMAN NUMERALS. EXAMPLES: 'ARTICLE I - DEFINITIONS', 'ARTICLE II. PURCHASE AND SALE', 'SECTION 5. CONFIDENTIALITY'. THESE CREATE THE PRIMARY DOCUMENT STRUCTURE.

Apply to subsection headings within articles. Usually bold or underlined, numbered with decimals (1.1, 2.3) or letters. Located between ArticleHeading and body text. Examples: '2.1 Purchase Price', '3.2 Payment Terms', '(a) Delivery Schedule'. Creates secondary structure level.

Apply to third-level headings within clauses. Often uses letters (a), (b) or roman numerals (i), (ii) with bold or italic text. Examples: '(a) Initial Payment', '(i) First Installment'. Nested under ClauseHeading.

Apply to regular paragraph text forming the main contract content. Standard prose without special formatting, numbers, or bullets. Contains the actual terms, conditions, and legal language. Most common style in document. NOT for headings, lists, definitions, or signature blocks.

Apply to body text paragraphs that are intentionally indented from the left margin, often for sub-provisions or continuation of numbered items. Same as BodyText but with left indentation. Use when source paragraph has leftIndent > 0 but is not a list item.

Apply to paragraphs that are part of a numbered sequence using (1), (2), (3) or 1., 2., 3. or (a), (b), (c) patterns. Check listFormatting.hasList=true with SimpleNumbering or ListNumOnly types. Used for enumerated obligations, conditions, or requirements.

Apply to paragraphs that are part of a numbered sequence using (1), (2), (3) or 1., 2., 3. or (a), (b), (c) patterns and should be one level below because they are sub-sections of a bulleted or numbered list. Check listFormatting.hasList=true with SimpleNumbering or ListNumOnly types. Used for enumerated obligations, conditions, or requirements.
Apply to paragraphs with bullet points (•, -, ○). Check listFormatting.hasList=true with Bullet type. Used for non-sequential lists of items, features, or conditions where order doesn't matter.

Apply to paragraphs with bullet points (•, -, ○) and should be one level below because they are sub-sections of a bulleted or numbered list. Check listFormatting.hasList=true with Bullet type. Used for non-sequential lists of items, features, or conditions where order doesn't matter.

Apply to 'WHEREAS' clauses or recitals at the beginning of contracts. Usually starts with 'WHEREAS', 'RECITAL', or similar. Provides background context before the operative provisions. Often indented or italicized. Found between parties identification and 'NOW THEREFORE'.

Apply to quoted material, excerpts from other documents, or text that should stand apart from main body. Usually indented from both margins. May be italicized. Used for citations, referenced provisions, or formal quotations.

Apply to indented quoted material, excerpts from other documents, or text that should stand apart from main body. Usually indented from both margins. May be italicized. Used for citations, referenced provisions, or formal quotations, where this should be indended, for example if part of a numbered or bulleted sequence.

Apply to paragraphs at the document start or end that identify the contracting parties or the signature block or an added list of documents and annexes. Contains party names, addresses, and defined short names, or other text that appears outside the structured main body of the document. Examples: 'ABC Corporation, a Delaware corporation (\"Buyer\")' or 'between: [Party A] and [Party B]'.

Apply to transitional paragraphs like 'NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of...' or 'NOW THEREFORE, the parties agree as follows:'. Marks transition from recitals to operative provisions. Usually one paragraph, often all caps start.

Apply to footnote content, usually smaller font, found at page bottom. May start with superscript number. Provides supplementary information or citations. Rarely used in contracts but common in memos and opinions.
